Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Support for 23rd International Colloquium on the Dynamics of Explosions and Reactive Systems, Irvine, California, July 24-29, 2011

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1120020
Dunn-Rankin

This proposal is for support of US students and junior researchers to attend the International Colloquium on the Dynamics of Explosions and Reactive Systems (ICDERS). The meeting is held biannually in the years when the Combustion Symposium is not held. The host organization is formally the Institute for the Dynamics of Explosions and Reactive Systems (IDERS, a non-profit organization registered in the state of Washington, USA, but the conference is essentially organized by the hosting institution. The 23rd ICDERS meeting will be held at the University of California, Irvine, July 24-29, 2011. It has been 10 years since the meeting was last held in the United States. Recent prior Symposia include: Minsk, Belarus, 2009; Poitiers, France, 2007; Montreal, Canada, 2005; Hakone, Japan, 2003.

Intellectual Merit:
ICDERS is the longest running specialist meeting of the Combustion Institute, and is the most important international meeting on combustion and explosions that focuses on the dynamic elements of reactive systems. It focuses on combustion and explosion dynamics, the following lists the topics from the session titles at the most recent past meeting in Minsk: 1) Deflagration-Detonation Transition; 2) Detonation - Structure; 3) Modeling of Reactive Systems; 4) Jet Ignition; 5) Combustion Induced Vortex Breakdown; 6) Flames in IC Engines; 7) Multiphase Reactive System; 8) Diagnostics; 9) Fires; 10) Pulsed Detonation Engines and Rotating Detonation Engines; 11) Fast Flames; 12) Ignition; 13) Soot; 14) Flames; 15) Hydrocarbon Ignition and Combustion; 16) Detonation Initiation; 17) Numerical Simulation; 18) Detonation Structure and Chemical Reaction; 19) Detonation Multiphase; 20) Electric and Magnetic Effects; 21) Flame Instabilities; 22) Flames in Channels; 23) Chemical Kinetics; 24) Explosions; 25) Micro and Mesoscale Combustion; 26) Multiphase Combustion; 27) Various other Topics.

Broader Impacts:
The current plan includes (1) a special grad-student/post-doc poster session and reception that allows younger scientists to interact directly with each other. (2) Discounted registration for selected U.S. researchers who have recently graduated (since they cannot get the student rate and might not have the resources for a full registration to present material that is not associated with their current position). (3) Graduate student registration waivers for student presenters to encourage their attendance and participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Over 80% of the world’s energy production and use is based on the combustion of fossil fuels.  Combustion is ubiquitous in traditional energy conversion systems such as automotive engines, stationary and aircraft gas turbines, rocket and space propulsion, electrical power generation, industrial furnaces, and home and institutional space heating.  The world’s dependence on combustion processes has led to many technological challenges including air quality, energy efficiency, global warming, and fire/explosion safety.  Thus, combustion remains an active, vital area of research worldwide.  The International Colloquium on the Dynamics of Explosions and Reactive Systems (ICDERS) is the longest running specialist meeting of the Combustion Institute, and is the most important international meeting on combustion and explosions that focuses on the dynamic elements of reactive systems.   The meeting is held biannually in the years when the Combustion Symposium is not held.  The ICDERS conference is a compact international meeting that is large enough to be comprehensive and small enough to allow focused discussion and interaction.

The 2011 International Colloquium on the Dynamics of Explosions and Reactive Systems filled a 5-day agenda including specially organized sessions on subjects such as heterogeneous blast wave dynamics, dynamic vapor cloud explosions, and supersonic combustion.  Approximately 250 contributed oral presentations in 4 parallel sessions were on the program, along with 100 poster papers on a wide range of combustion topics. 

Broader Impacts

As with all combustion conferences it is easy to describe the broader impacts of this meeting.  U.S. students attending this Colloquium had a unique opportunity to meet the most respected members of the international combustion community interested in the dynamics of explosions and reactive systems, to discuss their research with them, and to exchange ideas with both senior researchers as well as their student peers from around the world.  The ICDERS conferences involved participants from more than 25 countries, providing an extensive international flavor and the concomitant connectons.  There was also a special young researcher event that let the graduate students from around the world interact directly with each other as peers, leading to connections that they will exploit in their future careers.

In addition, the host institution (UCI) has a strong NSF-funded Alliance for Minority Participation (CAMP).  The ICDERS conference overlaped with two minority STEM major activities at UCI, the CAMP Summer Scholars program and the CAMP Summer Science Academy.  In the former, minority students carry out summer research in faculty laboratories, and in the latter, entering freshmen minority students receive an intense introduction to university life and study.  These students were invited to act as observers at the ICDERS meeting, providing them a remarkable interaction with research at the highest level.

In the end, the conference had 350 attendees, with more than 350 technical presentations.  The conference produced a proceedings of the papers presented that was available to attendees.  The abstracts are available publicly via the website of the conference -- http://icders2011.eng.uci.edu.  Authors who presented papers at the meeting are encouraged to submit full-length versions of the work for Special Issues in two relevant journals for broader dessimination (Combustion Science and Technology and Shock Waves).

The image is the logo for the meeting, showing a fuel-lean flame in dynamic motion.  This flame produces lower emissions than technologies in current use; it represents the kinds of next generation results that conferences of this kind can foster.  Also shown are the Board of Directors for the Institute that officially hosts the conference.
